title: Married billionaire tycoon 'bought woman's silence after she claimed he gave her two STDs'
text:
Woman had threatened to reveal details after she claimed he had given her two sexually-transmitted infections

A well-known billionaire has paid a woman £1million to stop her speaking about a relationship she claimed left her with two sex infections, it has emerged.

The married man - who is said to be a household name — was granted a High Court injunction to protect his identity on Friday.

Identified only as Mr J and Ms O, the pair started a secret fling in 2017 which lasted for a year.

But after it ended, it is claimed the woman began threatening to revealing details of the relationship according to court documents.

The married man - who is said to be a household name — was granted a High Court injunction to protect his identity on Friday

The woman instructed a US attorney to alleged the man had given her the two STIs in July 2018.

Mr J denied this and offered to exchange medical records at the High Court.

Presiding over the case, Judge Mr Justice Pepperall referred to correspondence between Ms O's US attorney and Mr J's London-based lawyers Carter Ruck.

It is alleged that the woman's lawyer said: 'It seems that your client has had unprotected sex with a number of different women.

'If he is going to go around having sex with multiple different partners without a condom then he's going to get them sick and he's going to have to pay for it.'

Justice Pepperall's ruling will keep both parties anonymous, and the other elements of the case over payments will be ruled upon later

The billionaire then agreed to pay $1.5million, with Ms O signing a statement in August 2018 that she had 'totally and completely obliterated' all evidence of their relationship.

Mr J then paid the first $1million to her, with the rest due at a later date.

But this April Mr J was told by a mutual pal, dubbed Ms X, that she had been shown snaps of the former lovers together.

In August, Mr J's lawyers demanded repayment — while Ms O claimed her privacy rights had been breached under EU law.

Justice Pepperall's ruling keeps both parties anonymous, and the other elements of the case will be ruled upon later.
description: The unidentified billionaire, believed to be a household name, is alleged to have given a woman he was having an extra-marital affair with two sexual diseases.
